Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

The "Optics for Animation Artists" project is developing and assessing curricular materials for teaching optics to art students, in particular those majoring in animation, illustration, and related fields such as architecture, industrial design, graphic design, new media, and fine arts. The San Jose State University group brings together two physicists of considerable experience in this area with two very active animation and illustration artists, and the project is being completed within the globally recognized animation region of the San Francisco Bay area. Many within the exploding field of professional animators identify the technological facet of their craft as the most rapidly advancing (and now indispensible) component of their industry. Animation and illustration students are keenly aware of these trends and understand that their future careers require them to have an increasingly broad exposure to science.

The project creates visual assets (illustrations, videos, etc.), develops annotated slides, designs classroom demonstrations and studio activities, formulates lighting projects, and then combines all these elements into lecture packets and tutorials. Developed materials are being tested in three settings: as embedded lectures within existing art classes, as special Master Class workshops, and in a newly developed general education physics course designed specifically for animators and illustrators. The project is transforming one portion of undergraduate science education by bringing this aspect of physical science directly to a motivated and underserved audience, namely artists without the mathematics background required by advanced science courses. Modules being produced are subject to a careful assessment to enable a broad impact on U.S. art education and also to encourage their use in other liberal arts classes that focus on science and the arts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of animation, including feature-length films and video game design, is a multi-billion dollar industry. The United States has always been a leader in animation, starting with Walt Disney and continuing with modern studios, such as Pixar and DreamWorks. Besides the entertainment industry, modern animation is used extensively in training, education, scientific visualization, industrial design, architecture, and many other fields.

Art departments and film schools at universities as well as animation programs at high schools have expanded in recent years to meet the growing demands for animation artists. Professional animators identify the technological facet as the most rapidly advancing (and now indispensible) component of their industry. Animation and illustration students are keenly aware of these trends and understand that their future careers require them to have a broader exposure to science than in the past.

The vision of the TUES program is excellent STEM education for all undergraduate students. For the most part there is little overlap between art and science in the typical university curriculum and physics courses for visual artists are extremely rare. The “Optics for Animation Artists” project was designed to transform undergraduate education by bringing STEM to an underserved audience, namely artists without the mathematics background required by advanced science courses.

Our project has developped curriculum materials for teaching optics to art students, in particular those majoring in animation, illustration, and related fields such as architecture, industrial design, graphic design, new media, and fine arts. These materials have been incorporated into several courses at our university and are freely available from our website www.AnimationPhysics.org. Furthermore, we wrote and published a short book entitled Optics: A Handbook for Artist, which is available as a free downoad (tinyurl.com/OpticsArtists).

At our university, the greatest benefit we’ve seen resulting from this project is that it has spurred a tremendous increase in the curiosity of our students towards all manner of visual effects. We regularly overhear art students speaking—knowledgably—about “light scattering” and the “angle of incidence.”  They ask sophisticated questions about how light changes over distance, and whether a particular lighting setup will generate a noticeable penumbra. They regularly send us photos of some optical phenomenon that they saw and were excited to share because they understood it. This spontaneous feedback tells us that the project has inspired students from a non-scientific discipline to exercise their curiosity in regards to science. Physics is no longer an abstract pursuit or an alien field of study. It is a topic that affects their observations on a daily basis, and thus their work as artists.
